docs.lead_paragraph: MaryBeth Zea of Little Falls, Minn., was only 28, married but childless, when breast cancer struck in 1988. The surgeon who performed her mastectomy told her that because her cancer was not hormone-sensitive, pregnancy would probably not make much difference to her chances of a recurrence. He told her that pregnancy was a personal choice. But MaryBeth was afraid that the stress of pregnancy and its outpouring of hormones could stimulate a regrowth of cancer. She also feared what would become of a baby if she should get sick again. And so she chose to remain childless and devote herself instead to her marriage and career, now as a still-healthy portrait photographer.

headline.main: Cancer and Childbirth: Mutually Exclusive No Longer

docs.abstract: Article on changes in cancer treatment aimed at preserving fertility while curing cancers; notes more than 75 percent of children with cancer are being cured, but little is known about side effects of treatment beyond first decade; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a gynecologist for more than 20 years, Dr. Hilda Hutcherson has seen just about everything. So it hasn't surprised her in the least to have younger and younger girls come into her office at the New York Center for Women's Sexual Health at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center to ask for birth control advice. But even Dr. Hutcherson, who regularly sees adolescent girls as patients and gives talks on sexuality in schools, was shocked to find that girls as young as 11 and 12 are engaging in sexual activity. (And yes, that includes many girls from the Westchester suburbs.) Puberty is hitting earlier than ever before, and sexual references are unavoidable -- in the news, on television and billboards. Children are learning about much more than the birds and the bees when they still believe in the tooth fairy.

headline.main: What Your Child Isn't Telling You About S-E-X

docs.abstract: Gabrielle Glaser County Lines column on sexual activity of children even as young as 11 and 12 in Westchester County, NY; gynecologist Dr Hilda Hutcherson, author of adult book, What Your Mother Never Told You About S-e-x, says she regularly sees adolescent girls as patients; guidance counselors, parents, and adolescents say children believe oral sex is not sex and that it has become a status symbol; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Egan Says Claims of Abuse Will Go Right to Prosecutors'' (news article, May 16):
docs.abstract: Letter from Gordon J Campbell, Safe Horizon, says clerical abuse cases rocking Roman Catholic Church should serve as wake-up call to all about prevalence and repercussions of child sexual abuse
